JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra;Mihai Poalelungi;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant is a company from the breakaway NORP region of GPE in the telecommunications field . It was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in PERSON . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Government of GPE adopted decision No . CARDINAL , under which private businesses from the breakaway NORP region of GPE could obtain temporary registration with ORG to facilitate their export operations by using NORP customs stamps .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Government of GPE adopted decision No . CARDINAL - CARDINAL , making it possible for the applicant company to obtain a licence in the telecommunications field after obtaining temporary registration . This decision was taken in private , however , it appeared later from the decision of ORG ( see below ) that the purpose of the decision was to unify the telecommunications systems of the CARDINAL banks of LOC and to re - establish telephone communications with the breakaway province .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company obtained temporary registration under NORP law in accordance with Government decision no . CARDINAL and was issued with a ORG registration number and a registration certificate by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company obtained , in accordance with Government decision no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL , CARDINAL licences from ORG for ORG ( “ ORG ” ) to provide mobile and fixed telephony services , for which it paid MONEY ( “ USD ” ) to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of the ORG decided against allowing the applicant company a presence in the NORP telecommunications market , and on DATE the President of GPE challenged Government decision no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL before ORG . The grounds for challenging the decision were , inter alia , that the price paid by the applicant company had been considerably lower than that paid by other similar companies present on the market and that the rules of fair competition had thus been infringed .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to suspend the applicant company ’s licences .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Government suspended decision no . CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE Government decision no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL was declared unconstitutional by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the applicant company that on DATE its licences had been withdrawn in view of the fact that its registration as a legal entity under NORP law had been terminated and in accordance with the ORG decision of DATE . The letter made reference to the provisions of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( b ) of LAW ( see below ) .

CARDINAL . It does not appear from the materials of the case that upon learning the above the applicant company challenged ORG decision to terminate its registration or ORG ’s decision to withdraw its licences . Instead , the applicant company requested on several occasions that the Government refund the money paid for the licences . Since the ORG refused to refund the money , on DATE the applicant company initiated proceedings before ORG claiming CARDINAL and default interest from the Government .
CARDINAL . During the proceedings ORG requested information from ORG concerning the applicant company . ORG informed the court that no company named ORG was registered in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG struck the applicant company ’s application off the list of cases , on the ground that it did not have standing to initiate a civil action because it was not registered as a legal entity in GPE or in any other country . The court ordered ORG to return to the applicant company the court fees paid by it . The court fees were paid by ORG to the applicant company ’s account .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant company appealed and argued , inter alia , that it had followed the rules instituted by the Government when it had obtained a temporary registration and had paid the money for the licences . It also argued that its registration under NORP law had never been formally cancelled .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant company ’s appeal and upheld the first - instance court ’s decision . It reached the same conclusion as the first - instance court , that the applicant company lacked capacity to plead before courts as it was legally nonexistent .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company wrote to ORG and inquired whether it was still registered as a legal entity in GPE . In a letter dated DATE ORG explained to the applicant that its registration had automatically became null when decision no . CARDINAL was suspended on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company wrote again to ORG and requested the refund of the money paid for the licences . In a letter dated DATE the Minister of Finance informed the applicant company that its request had been examined and asked the applicant company to provide details of its bank account . The applicant company complied , but no payment followed .

CARDINAL . According to sections DATE and CARDINAL of Law No . CARDINAL of DATE on the ORG registration of legal entities ( “ ORG DATE ” ) , the termination of registration of a legal entity can be carried out only on the basis of a request by the legal entity in question or on the basis of a court decision .

CARDINAL . According to section DATE ( CARDINAL ) ( b ) of PERSON No . CARDINAL of DATE on licensing ( “ LAW DATE ” ) , a licence can be withdrawn , inter alia , as a result of adoption of a decision terminating the state registration of the company . According to LAW ( CARDINAL ) of the same act , if a licence is withdrawn for any reason the licence fee shall not be refunded by the ORG .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL ( b ) of LAW provides that a court shall strike out applications lodged by incapable persons . According to LAW a legal entity acquires capacity ( dobândeşte capacitatea de folosinţă ) on registration by ORG , and loses capacity ( pierde capacitatea de folosinţă ) on removal from the registry of ORG .
